Homeless.

While all of the options have some potential to make for an interesting and compelling character, homelessness adds an extra layer of challenge and hardship to the character's journey. Being homeless means that the character has no stable place to call their own, no roof over their head, and no security in their daily life. This makes it much more difficult for them to stay on the straight and narrow, as they are constantly facing the threat of being forced to move on and start over again.

Additionally, homelessness can be a source of deep shame and humiliation for the character, which can make it even harder for them to admit their mistakes and seek help. They may feel like they have nowhere to turn, no one to trust, and no way to make things right. This can make for a powerful and emotional arc as the character struggles to overcome their past and build a better future.

Overall, while any of the options could work well for a reformed prisoner character, homelessness adds a unique and compelling twist to the story, and provides a strong foundation for exploring themes of redemption, resilience, and the human spirit.
